So let's say you are a telecom operator,
a communication service provider,

You are processing data

in transit, at rest, and also in use.

So the production of data
in transit and at rest,
these are well documented.

Confidential computing
is about protecting data
while in use.
And specifically at AWS,
we define confidential computing
as the use of specialized hardware
with the associated firmware and software
for the protection of data in use

while being processed
from unauthorized access.

And so how do we enable this
within the AWS ecosystem?
Right.
We have three key capabilities.
One, we have the AWS Nitro System.
Second, we have AWS Nitro Enclaves.

the third capabilities,
the Nitro Trusted Platform Module, TPM.
So,
I mean, before we explain,
let me just take a step back,

because before we explain
those three capabilities,
let's talk about two important dimensions

When you talk about unauthorized access,
you have to consider two dimensions.

Dimension one is protection
from the cloud operator.
In the case of you working with AWS,
it's protection from AWS, from us.
You want to protect your data from us.

Dimension two is protection
from yourself as a customer.
Let me give you examples.
This can be an admin of your workloads.
This can also be a supplier

to do managed operations on your behalf.

And this dimension two
also covers the cases
where you have a malicious admin,

a malicious third party that's
posing as an admin, right?

So now let's get back to

because this is where you

The AWS Nitro System is the foundation

With the AWS Nitro System,

there is no operator access
to your data or your codes.
Now let's talk about dimension two.
This is where AWS Nitro Enclave comes in.
Nitro Enclaves are hardened, secured,
and isolated computing environments.

And they provide additional
isolation capabilities
than what the Nitro System can provide.
This is addressing dimension two.

we have the Nitro TPM.

standard compliant device.

So we said Nitro Enclaves
are hardened, secure,
and isolated computing environments.

They're essentially highly
constrained virtual machines.

Their lifecycle, their existence
is tied to an EC2 instance.

And we often talk about
the parent instance.

Now, Nitro Enclaves,
they have no networking,
they have no administrative access,
they have no permanent storage.
And the only way to access the enclave
is via its parent instance.

They're also coming with
their own cryptographic keys.

And from a software
deployment point of view,
we're basically using the docker format

Now, they are not containers, right?

But we're using this
format for its convenience
and its developer friendliness.
From a capabilities point of view,

Nitro Enclaves have really
two key capabilities.
One of them is an attestation mechanism.

This can be used for the
enclave to prove its identity,
for example, to another service.
And also to authorize what codes
can run on the enclave.
They also have a first class integration

with the AWS Key
Management System, AWS KMS.

And this combination
is extremely powerful.
Why is that?
Because you can ensure, for example,
that only an enclave has the ability
to decrypt a specific piece of data
that you might have encrypted.

So from a value
perspective, Nitro Enclaves,

they can attest their identity,
they can authorize codes,
they're extremely flexible.

So what is mutual authentication?
In a mobile network,

the network wants to authenticate
the user, the subscriber.

Typically, that's going to

It wants to make sure

to use the network

Mutual authentication
is based on the exchange
of a set of cryptographic values
called authentication vectors, AVs.

And the generation of these
authentication vectors,

those AVs, is based on
cryptographic operation
that is applied on a shared secret key

that is available to both
the network and the user.
So when you start your smartphone,

the smartphone is going to
take the shared secret key

the authentication vector.
The network, in the network,
